questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of worsening chest pain and dyspnea. Six days ago, he fell in the shower and since then has had mild pain in his left chest. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) hematoma over the left lower chest. An x-ray of the chest shows fractures of the left 8th and 9th rib, increased opacity of the left lung, and mild tracheal deviation to the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admission to the ICU and observation
Needle thoracostomy in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line
Needle thoracentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line
Chest tube insertion in the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Most patients with a hemothorax will require admission to the ICU. However, a large hemothorax must be drained immediately because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

B) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a needle in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line can be used as an emergency treatment for tension pneumothorax because it allows the trapped air in the pleural cavity to escape. Tension pneumothorax may develop if a rib fracture causes a pulmonary laceration that fails to seal and can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and contralateral deviation of the trachea. However, a patient with pneumothorax would have hyperresonant lung fields on percussion instead of dullness on the affected site. Also, a chest x-ray would show increased radiolucency and decreased lung markings rather than increased opacity.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).

These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

C) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracocentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line, with the patient in a supine position, is used for diagnostic pleural taps. Needle aspiration is not the treatment of choice for a hemothorax because a drain with a larger caliber is required for complete evacuation of blood from the pleural cavity. Incomplete evacuation of blood may lead to clot formation and subsequently a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a hemothorax, urgent thoracotomy is indicated if more than 1500 mL of blood has been drained from the pleural cavity, if the rate of blood loss exceeds 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, and/or if multiple transfusions are required. However, thoracotomy is not the first-line therapy because a different procedure should first be employed to improve lung expansion and to assess the amount of blood loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from hemopericardium following thoracic trauma and manifests with dyspnea and chest pain. However, a hemopericardium usually develops following penetrating injuries to the chest wall and is unlikely in a patient with low-energy blunt chest trauma. Moreover, this patient has none of the classical clinical manifestations of cardiac tamponade, which include low systolic blood pressure (due to decreased stroke volume), distention of neck veins (due to impaired right ventricular filling), and/or muffled heart sounds. Tracheal deviation and increased lung opacity are not associated with isolated cardiac tamponade. Instead, a chest x-ray is likely to reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

F) CORRECT:

Chest tube insertion into the 4th to 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line is the treatment of choice for all patients with moderate to large hemothoraces. Alternatively, the chest tube can be inserted into lower intercostal spaces with ultrasound guidance. The chest tube should be placed posteriorly for optimal fluid drainage. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity will clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.

Thoracotomy is indicated if chest tube output is > 1500 mL directly after placement, 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, or if multiple transfusions are required.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopnea

The margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.

Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib
questions.hint: Chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion over the left lung base following a rib fracture in conjunction with this patient's x-ray findings (increased opacity and tracheal deviation to the contralateral side) suggest a large hemothorax.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed, and heart sounds would be muffled on auscultation. Also, tracheal deviation would not be present in an isolated case of cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial rupture would manifest with subcutaneous emphysema and hemoptysis. Clinical features of a pneumothorax such as hyperresonant lung fields would also be present in distal tracheobronchial tree injuries. The absence of any of these findings suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

C) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and deviation of the trachea to the opposite side. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed because the mediastinal shift that occurs with a tension pneumothorax compresses the superior vena cava. Also, lung fields on the affected side would be hyperresonant instead of dull on percussion.

D) INCORRECT:

A flail chest could manifest with respiratory distress and tachypnea. A patient with flail chest classically exhibits paradoxical movement of a part of the chest wall on respiration. Although this sign may be absent due to respiratory splinting, a mediastinal shift (tracheal deviation), decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion are not characteristic signs of a flail chest. The absence of bony crepitus also suggests that the patient does not have a rib fracture. A different diagnosis must be considered.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

E) CORRECT:

Hemothorax can develop following blunt chest trauma. This patient exhibits all the signs and symptoms of a massive hemothorax, i.e., tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, flat neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and dullness on percussion on the affected side, as well as tracheal deviation to the opposite side. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Treatment usually consists of chest tube insertion into the 4th–5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line in order to allow the blood to drain away and improve lung ventilation. Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows left-sided opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text: Six days after falling in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. There are faint expiratory wheezes throughout the lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Air between the pleura and chest wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trapped air between the pleura and chest wall is the underlying pathophysiology of pneumothorax. Given this patient's history of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath, pneumothorax should be considered as a possible diagnosis. A tension pneumothorax can cause tracheal deviation away from the affected side, due to increased intrathoracic pressure. However, x-ray findings in pneumothorax would include absent lung markings and areas of increased radiolucency rather than the large opacity and air-fluid level seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacteria in the pulmonary parenchyma (e.g., due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) would be consistent with bacterial pneumonia. Expected chest x-ray findings in bacterial pneumonia would also include a lobar opacity, but tracheal deviation and an air-fluid level, as seen here, would be unusual. Furthermore, this patient does not have fever or symptoms of pneumonia, making this unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of pulmonary edema may include dyspnea and low oxygen saturation due to impaired oxygenation. While both are seen in this patient, pulmonary edema alone would not cause such a pronounced air-fluid level on x-ray. Instead, it would appear as bilateral, patchy, confluent opacification, as the fluid is trapped inside the alveoli.

D) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic cells in the bronchi would be consistent with lung cancer, which this patient has risk factors for (smoking, age). An obstructive lung cancer could also cause tracheal deviation but would cause tracheal deviation towards the affected side, due to lung collapse, unlike what is seen here. This patient's large left-sided pleural effusion in the setting of recent fall make a different diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history of recent fall and x-ray findings of a large left pleural effusion with tracheal deviation are consistent with hemothorax. Trauma to the chest can cause the ribs to pierce the pleura and damage intrathoracic vessels, which can lead to accumulation of blood in the pleural space. There is tracheal deviation to the opposite side due to the increasing volume in the pleural space. A hemothorax cannot be diagnosed with x-ray alone (diagnosis usually requires CT imaging or thoracentesis) but given the patient's recent trauma, this is the most likely etiology.
questions.hint: The chest x-ray shows a left-sided opacity, blunting of the costophrenic angles, and mild tracheal deviation to the right.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic renal insufficiency presents with a chief complaint of altered mental status and a temperature of 39.5°C. His blood pressure is 104/64 mm Hg, his heart rate is 144 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute.
Initial laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 26,500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000). Urinalysis is positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase, shows 50 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and reveals gram-negative rods on Gram stain. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
The patient is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. Because of poor vascular access, a left-subclavian central venous catheter is placed (after several attempts); its position is verified by a portable chest radiograph.
Two hours later, despite continued resuscitation and medical therapy, the patient becomes acutely hypotensive with a blood pressure of 65/35 mm Hg. In addition, his supplemental oxygen requirement has increased from 2 to 15 liters per minute via a nonrebreather mask.
Physical examination reveals tracheal deviation to the right, absent breath sounds over the left chest, and dullness to percussion over the anterior and posterior left chest.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Placement of a large-bore thoracostomy tube
CT of the chest with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

More than 5 million central venous catheters are inserted in the United States annually. Risks associated with catheter placement include infection, as well as mechanical and thrombotic complications. The most common mechanical complications — arterial puncture, hematoma, pneumothorax, and hemothorax — have been reported in 5% to 19% of cases. Overall, internal jugular catheterization and subclavian venous catheterization carry similar mechanical risks (with a slightly higher incidence of pneumothorax/hemothorax with subclavian venous placement).

In this case, the patient shows signs and symptoms of a tension hemothorax as opposed to a pneumothorax. The key finding that suggests hemothorax instead of pneumothorax is dullness to percussion. This is a sign of fluid in the pleural space as opposed to air, which would be hyperresonant.

Suspected tension hemothorax, which is life-threatening, requires immediate decompression. A patient with worsening dyspnea, hypotension, diminished breath sounds with dullness to percussion, and tracheal deviation should be treated without a confirmatory chest radiograph so as to avoid delay. A hemothorax requires a large-bore chest tube (> 36F) to adequately drain fresh blood. Additionally, a large-bore tube will allow measurement of the rate of bleeding and help block the bleeding by allowing apposition of the pleural surfaces.

Key learning point: Management of a tension hemothorax requires immediate decompression of the affected side with a large-bore chest tube.

B) INCORRECT:

Unlike a pneumothorax, which can be rapidly decompressed with a large-caliber needle in the second or fifth intercostal space, a hemothorax requires a large-bore chest tube (>36F) to adequately drain fresh blood. Needle decompression would not allow adequate drainage of the blood causing the tension physiology. Needle decompression would not allow adequate drainage of the blood causing the tension physiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging would only delay potential life-saving treatment and is not recommended when immediate decompression is required.

D) INCORRECT:

A patient with worsening dyspnea, hypotension, diminished breath sounds with dullness to percussion, and tracheal deviation should be treated without a confirmatory chest radiograph so as to avoid delay. Imaging would only delay potential life-saving treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical thoracotomy and exploration may become necessary if >1500 mL of drainage occurs within the first 24 hours or if the patient experiences persistent, uncontrolled bleeding.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a fall from a ladder. He complains of left-sided chest pain and difficulty breathing. He appears diaphoretic and tachycardic. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds over the left chest (see report).


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
90/58 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
26/min


Chest X-ray: Significant opacification of the left hemithorax with a fluid level
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Needle decompression in the left second intercostal space
Insert a large-bore chest tube on the left side

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Needle decompression is indicated for tension pneumothorax, characterized by a hyperlucent hemithorax and absent lung markings. The chest x-ray shows opacification with a fluid level, consistent with a hemothorax, not a tension pneumothorax. Therefore, needle decompression is not appropriate in this scenario.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's presentation of tachycardia, hypotension, and respiratory distress, along with chest x-ray findings of significant opacification of the left hemithorax with a fluid level, suggests a traumatic hemothorax. Inserting a large-bore chest tube is crucial to evacuate the blood from the pleural space, allowing lung re-expansion and stabilizing hemodynamics. This intervention prevents complications such as fibrothorax and ongoing hemorrhage, aligning with trauma management protocols that prioritize respiratory and circulatory stabilization.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected hemothorax following trauma, chest tube insertion is the appropriate management to evacuate blood from the pleural space and allow lung re-expansion.

C) INCORRECT:

High-flow oxygen improves oxygenation but does not address the underlying issue of a large hemothorax. The patient's hemodynamic instability and chest x-ray findings indicate the need for chest tube insertion to evacuate blood and re-expand the lung, rather than solely providing supplemental oxygen.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis is useful for evaluating pleural effusions but is not appropriate for this patient. The hemodynamic instability and imaging findings indicate a significant hemothorax requiring immediate therapeutic intervention. Chest tube placement is necessary to rapidly evacuate blood and stabilize the patient, whereas thoracentesis is more suited for non-urgent fluid evaluation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after sustaining a stab wound to the left chest. A chest tube is placed, returning 1500 mL of blood, and an additional 400 mL drains over the next 20 minutes. He remains hypotensive despite aggressive fluid resuscitation. Breath sounds on the left are markedly diminished, and he appears increasingly diaphoretic.


Heart rate
130/min


Blood pressure
85/50 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
30/min


What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Increase intravenous fluids and monitor output
Insert an additional chest tube on the same side

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While fluid resuscitation is essential in hypovolemic shock, the massive chest tube output indicates a need for surgical intervention. Continuing fluids without addressing the bleeding source only provides temporary support. Persistent hypotension despite fluids suggests the need for operative repair to control hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is useful for stable patients when diagnosis is uncertain. However, in this hemodynamically unstable patient with massive hemothorax, immediate surgical intervention is required. Delaying for imaging could worsen the patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

The current chest tube is functioning, as evidenced by the large volume of blood drained. Additional chest tubes do not address the uncontrolled bleeding source. The diminished breath sounds are due to blood accumulation, not tube malposition.

D) CORRECT:

Massive hemothorax is indicated by an initial chest tube output exceeding 1500 mL or rapid ongoing bleeding, as seen with 1500 mL initially and 400 mL in 20 minutes. The patient's hypotension and diminished breath sounds suggest active intrathoracic hemorrhage. Emergent thoracotomy provides direct access to control bleeding, repair vascular injuries, and manage thoracic injuries. This intervention is crucial in unstable trauma patients to prevent further hemodynamic compromise and reduce mortality.

Key learning point: In cases of massive hemothorax with hemodynamic instability, immediate surgical intervention with thoracotomy is required to control bleeding and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: Six days after a fall in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a 50-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. On examination, there is dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. Faint expiratory wheezes are heard throughout the lungs. A chest x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his current condition?

choices.text: Air between the pleura and chest wall.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of pulmonary edema may include dyspnea and low oxygen saturation due to impaired oxygenation. While both are seen in this patient, pulmonary edema alone would not cause such a pronounced air-fluid level on x-ray. Instead, it would appear as bilateral, patchy, confluent opacification, as the fluid is trapped inside the alveoli.

B) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic cells in the bronchi would be consistent with lung cancer, which this patient has risk factors for (smoking, age). An obstructive lung cancer could also cause tracheal deviation but would cause tracheal deviation towards the affected side, due to lung collapse, unlike what is seen here. This patient's large left-sided pleural effusion in the setting of recent fall make a different diagnosis more likely.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's history of recent fall and x-ray findings of a large left pleural effusion with tracheal deviation are consistent with hemothorax. Trauma to the chest can cause the ribs to pierce the pleura and damage intrathoracic vessels, which can lead to accumulation of blood in the pleural space. There is tracheal deviation to the opposite side due to the increasing volume in the pleural space. A hemothorax cannot be diagnosed with x-ray alone (diagnosis usually requires CT imaging or thoracentesis) but given the patient's recent trauma, this is the most likely etiology.

Key learning point: Hemothorax is a pleural effusion caused by blood accumulation in the pleural space, often following chest trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Trapped air between the pleura and chest wall is the underlying pathophysiology of pneumothorax. Given this patient's history of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath, pneumothorax should be considered as a possible diagnosis. A tension pneumothorax can cause tracheal deviation away from the affected side, due to increased intrathoracic pressure. However, x-ray findings in pneumothorax would include absent lung markings and areas of increased radiolucency rather than the large opacity and air-fluid level seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacteria in the pulmonary parenchyma (e.g., due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) would be consistent with bacterial pneumonia. Expected chest x-ray findings in bacterial pneumonia would also include a lobar opacity, but tracheal deviation and an air-fluid level, as seen here, would be unusual. Furthermore, this patient does not have fever or symptoms of pneumonia, making this unlikely.
questions.hint: The chest x-ray shows a left-sided opacity, blunting of the costophrenic angles, and mild tracheal deviation to the right.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath after a fall from scaffolding. Vital signs are BP, 100/65; P, 105; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lower chest. Upright chest x-ray shows fluid level extending to the mid-lung field. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a moderate to large hemothorax based on diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion on physical examination, and a fluid level extending to the mid-lung field on upright chest x-ray. All patients with moderate or large hemothoraces require chest tube insertion at the 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line to evacuate blood and reexpand the lung.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate thoracotomy is indicated for massive hemothorax in patients with hemorrhagic shock, chest tube output of ≥ 1500 mL immediately upon placement, or chest tube output of 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours. This patient's presentation does not suggest massive hemothorax requiring immediate surgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracentesis is not indicated for traumatic hemothorax management. It is inadequate for evacuating the volume of fluid suggested by this patient's chest x-ray findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Serial observation with chest x-rays is only considered for small hemothoraces (< 300 mL), typically those that only have blunting of the costophrenic angle without significant fluid accumulation. This patient's hemothorax extends to the mid-lung field, indicating a moderate to large volume.

E) INCORRECT:

While CT chest can detect hemothoraces not visible on chest x-ray and identify additional injuries, this patient already has a clearly visible moderate to large hemothorax on plain radiography. CT is not required for management decisions when the diagnosis is evident on x-ray.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He complains of left-sided chest pain and significant shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 125/min, and respirations are 28/min. On examination, there is decreased air entry over the left lung base and extensive bruising over the left chest wall. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Dullness to percussion over the left lung base
Hyperresonance to percussion over the left lung base
Paradoxical movement of the left chest wall

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of blunt chest trauma with signs of hemorrhagic shock (hypotension, tachycardia) and unilateral decreased breath sounds is highly suspicious for a massive hemothorax. This condition involves a significant accumulation of blood in the pleural space, which compresses the underlying lung. On physical examination, this large volume of fluid will produce dullness to percussion over the affected area. This finding, along with decreased or absent breath sounds, is a classic sign of a large pleural effusion. In the setting of trauma, a pleural effusion is considered a hemothorax until proven otherwise. Management involves immediate fluid resuscitation and placement of a large-bore chest tube (thoracostomy).

B) INCORRECT:

Jugular venous distention (JVD) indicates elevated central venous pressure. This is a classic finding in obstructive shock due to conditions like tension pneumothorax or cardiac tamponade. However, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia are due to massive blood loss (hemorrhagic or hypovolemic shock), which leads to decreased central venous pressure and typically presents with flat neck veins.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation occurs when a significant pressure difference exists between the two sides of the mediastinum. In the case of a large left-sided hemothorax or tension pneumothorax, the increased pressure on the left would push the trachea away from the affected side (i.e., to the right). Tracheal deviation toward the affected side suggests volume loss in that hemithorax, such as in massive atelectasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperresonance to percussion is a classic finding in pneumothorax, where air accumulates in the pleural space. While a pneumothorax is a common result of chest trauma and also causes decreased breath sounds, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia strongly suggest significant blood loss, which is more consistent with a hemothorax. A collection of blood would cause dullness, not hyperresonance.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical chest wall movement is the pathognomonic sign of a flail chest, which results from multiple rib fractures in two or more places creating a free-floating segment. While a flail chest can be caused by a high-speed collision and can coexist with a hemothorax, the finding most directly related to the collection of fluid causing shock and decreased breath sounds is dullness to percussion.
questions.hint: This patient's hemodynamic instability in the setting of trauma and unilateral decreased breath sounds suggests significant bleeding into the pleural space.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He complains of left-sided chest pain and difficulty breathing. On arrival, he is anxious and in respiratory distress. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125/min, and respiratory rate is 26/min. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals bruising over the left chest wall. His trachea is midline, and his jugular veins are flat. Auscultation reveals absent breath sounds over the left lower lung fields, and there is dullness to percussion over the same area. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary contusion, or bruising of the lung parenchyma, is a common injury after blunt chest trauma that causes hypoxia. Auscultation in a pulmonary contusion typically reveals crackles or decreased, not absent, breath sounds. While percussion may be slightly dull, the profound dullness described here is more consistent with a large fluid collection in the pleural space.

B) INCORRECT:

Flail chest results from multiple contiguous rib fractures, leading to a segment of the chest wall that moves paradoxically with respiration. While this patient has experienced trauma and is in respiratory distress, the key finding of paradoxical chest wall movement is not described. The prominent findings of absent breath sounds and dullness point to a pathology within the pleural space rather than just a chest wall injury.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, often due to injury to the intercostal vessels or lung parenchyma from blunt or penetrating trauma. The combination of hypovolemic shock (hypotension, tachycardia) and flat jugular veins indicates significant blood loss. The physical exam findings of unilateral absent breath sounds and dullness to percussion are caused by the large volume of blood in the pleural space compressing the lung and preventing sound transmission. A massive hemothorax (>1500 mL of blood) is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate tube thoracostomy and urgent surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade is a cause of obstructive shock following chest trauma. While it causes hypotension and tachycardia, it is typically associated with jugular venous distention and muffled heart sounds, not the flat jugular veins and unilateral lung findings seen here. Breath sounds are usually equal bilaterally in isolated cardiac tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

A tension pneumothorax also presents with respiratory distress, shock, and unilateral absent breath sounds after trauma. However, it is characterized by hyperresonance to percussion due to trapped air, not dullness. Additionally, it causes obstructive shock, leading to jugular venous distention and tracheal deviation away from the affected side, neither of which is present in this patient.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He has severe left-sided chest pain and is in respiratory distress. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 125/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. On physical examination, there is significant bruising over the left lateral chest wall. His trachea is midline. Auscultation shows absent breath sounds over the left lower lung fields, and there is dullness to percussion over the same area. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition that can present with hypotension, tachycardia, respiratory distress, and unilateral absent breath sounds after trauma. However, it is characterized by hyperresonance to percussion due to trapped air, not dullness. Additionally, it typically causes obstructive shock with distended neck veins and tracheal deviation away from the affected side, neither of which is present here.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a massive hemothorax resulting from blunt chest trauma. The accumulation of blood in the pleural space leads to absent breath sounds and dullness to percussion on the affected side. The significant blood loss into the chest cavity causes hypovolemic shock, manifesting as hypotension, tachycardia, and flat neck veins. Respiratory distress and hypoxia occur due to lung compression and ventilation/perfusion mismatch. A massive hemothorax is a surgical emergency, typically defined as > 1500 mL of blood loss into the chest or ongoing bleeding, and requires immediate tube thoracostomy followed by potential thoracotomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can cause obstructive shock with hypotension and tachycardia in trauma. However, its classic signs include muffled heart sounds and distended neck veins due to impaired cardiac filling. This patient has flat neck veins, consistent with hypovolemia. Furthermore, cardiac tamponade does not cause unilateral absent breath sounds or dullness to percussion.

D) INCORRECT:

Flail chest occurs when multiple adjacent ribs are fractured in two or more places, leading to a freely moving segment of the chest wall. While it causes severe pain and respiratory distress, its hallmark physical finding is paradoxical chest wall motion. While flail chest can be associated with this patient's condition, it does not typically cause absent breath sounds or dullness to percussion.

E) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary contusion, or bruising of the lung parenchyma, is common after blunt chest trauma and can cause respiratory distress and hypoxia. However, auscultation would more likely show crackles or rhonchi rather than completely absent breath sounds. While a severe contusion can cause dullness to percussion, the profound hemodynamic instability (shock) is better explained by an alternative diagnosis.
questions.hint: In a trauma patient with unilateral absent breath sounds, the percussion note and the state of the neck veins are key findings that help differentiate between the most likely causes.
